main_headline: How to Have a Successful Virtual Happy Hour
snippet: The coronavirus has turned drinks at the bar into drinks in our individual homes, but that doesn’t mean you have to drink alone.

main_headline: Why Not Get Your Own Wind Turbine? Many Reasons
snippet: Also this week: Our reporter catches drones while on assignment, and Ban Ki-moon says America needs to change its tune on climate.

main_headline: A Guide to Pandemic Scams, and What Not to Fall For
snippet: Fraudsters see opportunities to target us in these uncertain times. Here are their most popular schemes and how we can protect ourselves.

main_headline: Court Dismisses Exxon’s Effort to Block Climate Investigation
snippet: A federal judge in New York called a lawsuit brought by Exxon Mobil against state attorneys general in New York and Massachusetts “implausible.”

main_headline: Young Adults Come to Grips With Coronavirus Health Risks
snippet: It can be a serious disease for younger people, and many millennials have chronic physical and mental health conditions.

main_headline: This Olympic Skier Wants to Save the World’s Snow
snippet: Also this week: Scientists win a $1 million prize for mapping peat. (Yes, peat.)

main_headline: Coronavirus May Lurk in Semen, Researchers Report
snippet: It was not clear whether the scientists had found infectious virus or inert fragments, so sexual transmission of the virus still seems very unlikely.

main_headline: The Amazon, Siberia, Indonesia: A World of Fire
snippet: The growing intensity of wildfires and their spread to new corners of the globe raises fears that climate change is exacerbating the dangers.

main_headline: Can an Old Vaccine Stop the New Coronavirus?
snippet: A tuberculosis vaccine invented a century ago is cheap and safe, and seems to bolster the body’s immune system.

main_headline: U.S. Climate Report Warns of Damaged Environment and Shrinking Economy
snippet: Without major action to rein in global warming, the American economy could lose 10 percent of G.D.P. by 2100, according to a report from 13 federal agencies.

main_headline: Help! The Coronavirus Struck and I Want a Refund
snippet: In this week’s column, Sarah Firshein investigates the ever-changing refund policies offered by travel companies.

main_headline: A Busy Week for Climate Scientists, and Climate Negotiators
snippet: We have a few highlights from two big climate meetings. Also, tips how to reduce your holiday food waste.

main_headline: E.P.A. Threatens Legal Action Against Sellers of Fake Coronavirus Cleaners
snippet: The federal government is asking online retailers to take unregistered products that falsely claim protection from coronavirus off the market.

main_headline: As Disasters Multiply, Billions in Recovery Funds Go Unspent
snippet: The slow pace of government aid has left Americans more vulnerable to Hurricane Dorian and other storms. Climate change is making the problem worse.

main_headline: For Runners, Is 15 Feet the New 6 Feet for Social Distancing?
snippet: When we walk briskly or run, air moves differently around us, increasing the space required to maintain a proper social distance.

main_headline: Why the Wilder Storms? It’s a ‘Loaded Dice’ Problem
snippet: Global warming is bringing an era of wilder, more dangerous rains. The good news is that we’re getting better at evacuating flood zones. The bad news is everything else.

main_headline: C.D.C. Releases Early Demographic Snapshot of Worst Coronavirus Cases
snippet: The agency’s study of hospitalizations for Covid-19 in March shows heightened numbers for those with underlying conditions, men and African-Americans.

main_headline: A Forecast for a Warming World: Learn to Live With Fire
snippet: The Kincade fire is burning more than 10,000 acres in California. Other areas of the country are experiencing drought so understanding fire is becoming ever more important.

main_headline: Smokers and Vapers May Be at Greater Risk for Covid-19
snippet: Tobacco and marijuana products damage lungs, where the virus does its harm. Health officials are urging people to quit, and temporary sales bans are even being discussed.

main_headline: Senate Passes a Sweeping Land Conservation Bill
snippet: Years in the works, the measure designates more than a million acres of wilderness for environmental protection and permanently reauthorizes a federal program to pay for conservation.

main_headline: Coronavirus Is Very Different From the Spanish Flu of 1918. Here’s How.
snippet: The fear is similar, but the medical reality is not.

main_headline: Australia, in a Victory for Coal, Clears the Way for a Disputed Mine
snippet: The final permit from regulators in Queensland came less than a month after a conservative coalition that champions coal won in national elections.

main_headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘In Her World, There’s No Pandemic Outside’
snippet: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

main_headline: Homes Are Being Built the Fastest in Many Flood-Prone Areas, Study Finds
snippet: Increased awareness of climate change has not diminished Americans' appetite for building homes in flood zones, new data show.

main_headline: Returning, and Awakening, to the Beauty of Rural Alabama
snippet: Having traveled to Alabama to wait out the coronavirus pandemic, a photographer reassesses his relationship with his childhood and his hometown.

main_headline: What Makes a Catastrophic Flood? And Is Climate Change Causing More of Them?
snippet: Floods are complicated. But here are simple answers to questions about flooding, climate change and staying safe when the water rises.

main_headline: Wondering About Social Distancing?
snippet: Answers to your most common questions about the best practices for stemming the tide of the coronavirus pandemic.

main_headline: Protesting Climate Change, Young People Take to Streets in a Global Strike
snippet: Anxious about the future and angry about the failure to curb the crisis, millions joined an urgent call for action against climate change.

main_headline: 5 Ways to Help Teens Manage Anxiety About the Coronavirus
snippet: Adults can help by making sure adolescents don’t overestimate the dangers or underestimate their ability to protect themselves.

main_headline: The Oil Industry’s Covert Campaign to Rewrite American Car Emissions Rules
snippet: Energy giants and conservative groups have been aggressively pushing Trump’s rollback of fuel efficiency rules for automobiles, a Times investigation found.

main_headline: How Not to Get Sick While Traveling
snippet: Should you wear a mask? Does airplane travel pose a greater risk? Do hand sanitizers work? Health professionals offer some tips.

main_headline: An Easy New Year’s Resolution: Help the Earth by Consuming Less
snippet: Also this week, the latest on the government shutdown and Democrats’ plans to address climate change.

main_headline: Watching the Pandemic Steal Intimate Moments From Teenagers
snippet: I’m afraid of holding a tight line of protection and having it snap under the weight of my almost-adult kid’s frustration.

main_headline: Americans Are Staying Home More. That’s Saving Energy.
snippet: A new study suggests that tech-fueled lifestyle changes that encourage Americans to travel less are saving energy. But the full picture may be murkier.

main_headline: With Crispr, a Possible Quick Test for the Coronavirus
snippet: A pioneer of the gene-editing technology has devised a diagnostic test for the infection that could be as simple as a pregnancy test.

main_headline: U.S. Pressure Blocks Declaration on Climate Change at Arctic Talks
snippet: The disagreement left the Arctic Council, which was formed to help protect the region's fragile environment, unable to issue a joint declaration for the first time in its history.

main_headline: Doctors and Patients Turn to Telemedicine in the Coronavirus Outbreak
snippet: The use of virtual visits climbs as a way of safely treating patients and containing spread of the infection at hospitals, clinics and medical offices.

main_headline: Faced With Drought, the Pharaohs Tried (and Failed) to Adapt
snippet: Ancient Egyptian leaders increased their empire’s grain production and crossbred cattle for resilience in an early effort to ward off climate disaster, a study shows.

main_headline: Get Ready for a Vaccine Information War
snippet: Social media is already filling up with misinformation about a Covid-19 vaccine, months or years before one even exists.

main_headline: A Toxic Tide Is Killing Florida Wildlife
snippet: Toxic algal blooms are not unusual off the state’s coast, but the current episode is the longest in more than a decade.

main_headline: Google Makes Stadia Gaming Service Free
snippet: The $130 entry fee is being waived indefinitely, as interest in playing video games surges during the coronavirus pandemic.

main_headline: E.U. Leaders Fail to Strengthen Climate Target
snippet: A proposal to reduce the 28-country bloc's net carbon emissions to zero by 2050 failed when eastern countries that are heavily dependent on coal raised objections.

main_headline: How Coronavirus Shifted the Stakes of Teenage Rebellion
snippet: Living with an invisible outside threat, and no visible outlet, forced my daughter and me to negotiate and reconcile — and fast.

main_headline: How One Billionaire Could Keep Three Countries Hooked on Coal for Decades
snippet: The story of a mining project in Australia helps to explain why the world keeps burning coal despite the profound risk it poses to the future.

main_headline: Exercising Outdoors With a Face Mask
snippet: Many of you had questions about running or cycling while wearing a face mask. Here’s what the experts have to say.

main_headline: Bigger, Faster Avalanches, Triggered by Climate Change
snippet: A deadly 2016 glacier collapse in Tibet surpassed scientists’ expectations — until it happened again. They worry it’s only the beginning.

main_headline: ‘I Feel Like I Have Five Jobs’: Moms Navigate the Pandemic
snippet: Families are scrambling to balance work and child care in a society where women still do most of the domestic tasks. Will a worldwide emergency change anything?

main_headline: Five Affordable, Effective Alternatives to Disposable Cleaning Products
snippet: From single-use cleaning wipes to detachable toilet wands, disposable cleaning products are often more expensive and less effective than the reusable products they replace.

main_headline: Will Protests Set Off a Second Viral Wave?
snippet: Across the country, mayors, public health experts and other officials worry that even though many protesters are wearing masks, the risk of new coronavirus cases will increase as thousands gather.

main_headline: Your Recycling Gets Recycled, Right? Maybe, or Maybe Not
snippet: Plastics and papers from dozens of American cities and towns are being dumped in landfills after China stopped recycling most “foreign garbage.”

main_headline: FOMO Is Over. Give In to the Joy of Letting Go.
snippet: As the days of quarantine drag on, many women are reveling in the relinquishment of high heels, painful waxes and constricting garments.

main_headline: Environmentalists and Nuclear Power? It’s Complicated
snippet: This week: Environmentalists and nuclear power make odd bedfellows, the world’s shipping sector charts a course, and a handy guide helps you reduce your own carbon footprint.

main_headline: Weighing Risks for My Patients at a Time of Covid-19
snippet: When should the fear of catching a virus, and one that usually causes a mild infection, outweigh the need to address urgent medical issues?

main_headline: Even as Floods Worsen With Climate Change, Fewer People Insure Against Disaster
snippet: The Midwest floods have highlighted a gap in disaster readiness: Fewer Americans are buying flood insurance, even as climate change increases their risk.

main_headline: Sexting, Consent and the ‘Quaranteen’
snippet: Guidance for parents on talking to teens about consent while on lockdown. Hint: Use French fries as an example.

main_headline: How to Break Your Single-Use Plastics Habit
snippet: Ditch your one-and-done straws, spoons, and containers with this kit of affordable, reusable stand-ins.

main_headline: A Promising Treatment for Coronavirus Fails
snippet: Researchers had hoped that antiviral drugs would help patients, but a new study from China said that one antiviral drug combination didn’t work.

main_headline: Plastic Bags, or Paper? Here’s What to Consider When You Hit the Grocery Store
snippet: Plastic and paper both have downsides. Here are a few broad lessons to keep in mind.

main_headline: The Birds Are Not on Lockdown, and More People Are Watching Them
snippet: Bird-watching has surged in popularity during the pandemic. It’s easy to start, and you can do it anywhere — even from inside, and even in urban spaces.

main_headline: What Land Will Be Underwater in 20 Years? Figuring It Out Could Be Lucrative
snippet: Detailed information about climate risks is surprisingly hard to find. A Silicon Valley start-up is trying to change that.

main_headline: Alaska Tourism Officials See an Opportunity in Coronavirus
snippet: “If you’re interested in the Great Wall and ancient sites, Alaska also offers spectacular natural sites,” said one Anchorage tourism official.

main_headline: Senate Takes Step to Approve Drilling in Arctic Wildlife Refuge
snippet: The prospects for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas exploration are better than they have been in years.

main_headline: Zoom Fatigue: How to Politely Decline a Call During Quarantine
snippet: The normal boundaries that once dictated social etiquette have essentially dissolved. So how do you disconnect?

main_headline: Invasive Grasses May Worsen Wildfires, Study Suggests
snippet: Grasses that have encroached from other regions can make wildfires more frequent, according to a new study.

main_headline: Surge of Virus Misinformation Stumps Facebook and Twitter
snippet: Secret labs. Magic cures. Government plots. Despite efforts by social media companies to stop it, false information about the coronavirus is proliferating around the world.

main_headline: Becoming Greta: ‘Invisible Girl’ to Global Climate Activist, With Bumps Along the Way
snippet: A Swedish girl’s solitary act of civil disobedience has turned her into a symbol for climate action. But her path hasn’t been easy.

main_headline: Online Help to Stay Sober During a Pandemic
snippet: Though face-to-face counseling and in-person group meetings have been suspended to curb the spread of the coronavirus, there are many virtual options newly available for support.

main_headline: The Immense, Eternal Footprint Humanity Leaves on Earth: Plastics
snippet: More than 8 billion metric tons of plastic have been made since the 1950s, researchers found. Because it does not degrade, most is still in the environment....

main_headline: Children and Coronavirus: Research Finds Some Become Seriously Ill
snippet: A study of more than 2,000 children with the virus in China found that babies were especially vulnerable to developing severe infection.

main_headline: 6 Things You’re Recycling Wrong
snippet: Can you recycle coffee cups or greasy pizza boxes? If you’re tossing things in the recycling bin out of sheer hope, you might be an “aspirational recycler.”

main_headline: Airbnb Raises $1 Billion to Stockpile Cash in Pandemic
snippet: The home rental company raised new funding as its business has been roiled by the coronavirus.

main_headline: Automakers Shift Gears on Climate Change
snippet: A conversation with the oceanographer Sylvia Earle. Also this week: We ask automakers about climate science, and forecasters look forward to spring.

main_headline: When Coronavirus Care Gets Lost in Translation
snippet: Medical interpreters must now work remotely, multiplying the challenges for front-line doctors and non-English-speaking patients.

main_headline: Cash for Carbon: Schumer Climate Plan Would Help Consumers Buy Electric Cars
snippet: A $450 billion climate change proposal from Senator Chuck Schumer would give consumers vouchers to buy American-made electric and hybrid cars and trucks.

main_headline: What’s Scaring the Pediatricians
snippet: Children are not the focus of the pandemic. But pediatricians are worried for children and families, for now and for the future.

main_headline: Climate Change and the Elections: Five Takeaways
snippet: Carbon taxes, renewable energy and climate bipartisanship were all on the ballot in various forms. Here's how they fared.

main_headline: Gyms and Coronavirus: What Are the Risks?
snippet: Sweat cannot transmit the virus but high-contact surfaces, such as barbells, can pose a problem, a doctor said.

main_headline: Climate Change Denialists Say Polar Bears Are Fine. Scientists Are Pushing Back.
snippet: In a new study, researchers single out a blog run by a Canadian zoologist as a primary source of dubious information about the status of polar bears.

main_headline: How to Clean Your Phone to Help Protect Against Coronavirus
snippet: It’s one thing to stop touching your face. It’s another to stop touching the things that touch your face.

main_headline: The ‘Great Pacific Garbage Patch’ Is Ballooning, 87,000 Tons of Plastic and Counting
snippet: Floating between California and Hawaii, the trash zone is up to 16 times bigger than previously thought, a new study suggests, and is growing "exponentially."

main_headline: The Art of the Pitch in the Midst of a Pandemic
snippet: Publicists for products in the pipeline long before the outbreak struggle to find the right tone.

main_headline: 5 Takeaways From The Times’s ClimateTECH Conference
snippet: At the gathering of technology and business leaders in San Francisco, discussion ranged from big data to lab-grown meat to a new candidacy for governor.

main_headline: Voices From Travel’s Frontlines: ‘Fasten Your Seatbelts’
snippet: We spoke with eight travel and hospitality workers, from California to Croatia, who have been working as the coronavirus spreads. They shared similar concerns about an uncertain future.

main_headline: One Thing You Can Do: Switch to a Green Energy Provider
snippet: Also, reporters, activists and world leaders get set for climate week.

main_headline: How to Tell if It’s More Than Just a Bad Mood
snippet: It is understandable if the coronavirus pandemic has put you in a funk, but depression should be evaluated and treated.

main_headline: We’re Covering Heritage Sites Threatened by Climate Change. The List Just Got Longer.
snippet: A new study says some of the most important ancient places in the Mediterranean might not survive global warming.

main_headline: Gargling for Coronavirus? What Science Can Tell Us
snippet: There is no firm proof that gargling prevents respiratory infections caused by coronavirus — or any virus or bacteria. But there’s also little downside.

main_headline: Companies See Climate Change Hitting Their Bottom Lines in the Next 5 Years
snippet: Some of the world's largest companies estimate they face roughly $1 trillion in climate-related risks, with most of that looming in just the next five years.

main_headline: Most New York Coronavirus Cases Came From Europe, Genomes Show
snippet: Travelers seeded multiple cases starting as early as mid-February, genomes show.

main_headline: Lawmakers, Lobbyists and the Administration Join Forces to Overhaul the Endangered Species Act
snippet: In recent weeks, more than two dozen measures have been proposed to remove protections for species and weaken the law, which critics say impedes people’s livelihoods.

main_headline: Why Rural America’s Digital Divide Persists
snippet: The pandemic is making clear that rural Americans are left behind. Less clear is how to fix it.

main_headline: Heat Wave Nudged the Planet to Its Hottest June, European Forecasters Say
snippet: A United States government analysis due this month is expected to reach similar conclusions, though the rankings of record months might differ slightly.

main_headline: A Privacy Absolutist Isn’t So Sure Anymore
snippet: The urgency of the pandemic has made Charlie Warzel, an Opinion writer for The Times, question his beliefs on the dangers of location tracking.

main_headline: Solar Power Is Burning Bright. But It’s Hardly Twilight for Fossil Fuels.
snippet: The world added more solar power than any other energy source in 2017. But it's still a tiny fraction of total electricity.

main_headline: What We Can Learn From Endurance Athletes About Getting Through This Pandemic
snippet: Long-distance runners, cyclists and triathletes can teach us about how to move through extended periods of discomfort.

main_headline: Three Campaign Ads That Are Putting Climate Change on the Agenda
snippet: Across the country, there’s been a small explosion of campaign ads about global warming.

main_headline: Should I Make My Own Mask?
snippet: The advice from public health officials has been confusing, leaving us to decide whether a D.I.Y. mask is better than nothing.

main_headline: How Record Heat Wreaked Havoc on Four Continents
snippet: We talked to people who found themselves on the front lines of climate change this year. Here are their stories.

main_headline: F.D.A. Warns 7 Companies to Stop Claiming Silver and Other Products Treat Coronavirus
snippet: The Food and Drug Administration and the Federal Trade Commission said the claims threaten public health because consumers might stop or delay appropriate medical treatment.

main_headline: ‘Like a Terror Movie’: How Climate Change Will Cause More Simultaneous Disasters
snippet: By the end of this century, some parts of the world could face as many as six climate-related crises at the same time, researchers have concluded.

main_headline: To My Husband in Quarantine on Day 18
snippet: Incurable cancer and chemo have devastated my immune system. My husband’s strict isolation is an act of Covid-19 contagion chivalry.

main_headline: 30 Vaquita Porpoises Are Left. One Died in a Rescue Mission.
snippet: Scientists called off an effort to save one of the world’s rarest marine mammals — the vaquita — when one died after being captured for rehabilitation.

main_headline: What if I Need to Go on a Ventilator?
snippet: A critical care doctor explains what treatment for coronavirus looks like in the intensive care unit.

main_headline: The World Is Embracing S.U.V.s. That’s Bad News for the Climate.
snippet: For the first time last year, S.U.V.s made up more than one in three cars sold globally as drivers in China, Australia and Europe ditched sedans.

main_headline: China Silences Critics Over Deadly Virus Outbreak
snippet: Beijing has responded faster to the new threat than it did with SARS, but it still silences and punishes those who veer from the official line, with potentially damaging consequences.

main_headline: Climate Lawsuits, Once Limited to the Coasts, Jump Inland
snippet: Local governments in California and New York City have sued oil and gas giants. Now Boulder and two Colorado counties have joined the fight.

main_headline: Coronavirus Infections May Not Be Uncommon, Tests Suggest
snippet: Two preliminary efforts to survey citizens for antibodies to the virus have produced controversial results.

main_headline: Want Cleaner Air? Try Using Less Deodorant
snippet: Consumer products like perfume, pesticides and paint can contribute as much to city air pollution as cars.

main_headline: Polio and Measles Could Surge After Disruption of Vaccine Programs
snippet: A new study of 129 countries found that the interruption of inoculation efforts could put 80 million babies at risk of getting deadly, preventable diseases.

main_headline: Pictures From Youth Climate Strikes Around the World
snippet: Children and young adults around the world skipped school en masse Friday to demand action on climate change.
